head.title: Ode to Winter.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 4, 1796), p. 4.

lg.l: Cease they frowns, rude winter Cease,
Nor blow thy dreadful blasts forward
Methinks thou would’it all nature freeze,
And all our suff’rings disregard.
See the Mountains white with snow,
That once were cloth’d in smiling Green;
And see the vallies deep below,
That once so beauteously were seen.
Behold all nature hush’d and still,
No pleasures here to intervene,
Nothing the dreadful waste to fill
Nought to refresh the dreary scene
The lads and lasses croud the fire,
Reciting all their Goblin Tales:
Or list’ning to some ancient fire,
When every other pleasure fails.
But winter! Short is thy rude reign,
For in three months thou art no more;
And spring will then return again,
Their cheerful gambols to restore.
